A simple solution to the test ordering problem would be to define your
own "OrderedTestSuite" class that maintains the order in which things
were added to the suite.  The main problem with this is hooking it into
JUnit's test runner -- that involves some minor hacking.  Alternately,
you could define your own junit.framework.TestSuite with the desired
semantics and place it before JUnit in your classpath; the test runners
should then use your version of the class instead.

--Sameer

> I've been relying upon the undocumented behavior in JUnit's reflection
> support.  Reflection seems to return methods based on their order within
> the class file, and JUnit's Result stores failures in a vector.
> Vector's elements() method is documented as returning the contents in
> vector order.
> 
> So, basically, I write my tests in order, simplest first, most complex
> last, and it comes out in the right order if I use have JUnit use
> reflection to identify the test methods.
> 
> Naturally, if Kent or Erich change the Result class, I'm hosed.
> 
> If you wanted to do this "right", you could extend TestRunner and
> replace printFailures() with a version which sorts the enumeration based
> on whatever criteria you like.  Method name comes to mind as something
> easy to use.
> 
> > Personnally I'm not even sure it's worth it, but I wanted to share
> > that idea with people on the list.
>  
> Oh, I think it's worth it.  The last time I brought it up I got
> flamed. :p I hope you fare better than I did.
